title: 2¬† Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: NVivo Course
text:
1 Welcome to the NVivo Course
This course is designed to provide you with a comprehensive introduction to NVivo, with a specific focus on working with interview transcripts for qualitative analysis.
Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or someone revisiting NVivo after a break, this tutorial walks you through all the essentials, from opening the software to importing and working with your data.

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.1 Who Is This Tutorial For?

Students or researchers conducting qualitative research
NVivo users working with interview transcripts, focus groups, or documents
Those wanting a guided, self-paced learning resource

No prior experience with NVivo is required.

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.2 What Will You Learn?
By the end of this course, you‚Äôll know how to:

Navigate the NVivo 14 interface with confidence
Create and manage NVivo projects
Create documents directly within NVivo for notes or journaling
Prepare and import transcripts for analysis
Understand best practices for organising qualitative data

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.3 What‚Äôs Covered
This course is divided into the following foundational topics:

Opening and setting up NVivo
Understanding the interface
Creating internal documents
Importing and preparing transcripts

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.4 Who Created This Course?
This tutorial was developed by the Data Analytics Service at the University of Sheffield.

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.5 How to Use This Tutorial
You can move through the chapters in order or jump to the sections most relevant to your workflow. Each page stands on its own, but they work best as a step-by-step guide.
To begin, select a chapter from the sidebar or the NVivo Basics section in the table of contents.

title: NVivo Course
text:
1.6 Help Us Shape This Course
We‚Äôre building this NVivo course to support learners like you and we‚Äôd love your input!
Click here to fill out a short feedback form
If you‚Äôd like to be notified when the course is ready, or if you have any questions, feel free to contact us at research-it@sheffield.ac.uk.
Let‚Äôs get started!

title: 2¬† Course Overview
text: 3 NVivo Course: Qualitative Data Analysis with NVivo

title: 2¬† Course Overview
text:
3.1 Chapters

3.1.1 1. Introduction

What this course is about
The challenges of qualitative data analysis
How software can support qualitative research
Overview of how NVivo supports:

Data storage
Coding and hierarchical organisation
Cases and attributes
Memos and annotations
Querying and visualisation




3.1.2 add setup section?


3.1.3 2. Getting Started with NVivo

Opening NVivo
Creating a new project
Understanding sample projects
Saving and managing your project files



3.1.4 3. Help and Support in NVivo

Using NVivo‚Äôs built-in Help
External tutorials and resources
Where to find community support



3.1.5 4. Navigating the NVivo Workspace

Overview of the interface
Navigation View, List View, Detail View
Context sensitivity: ribbons and tools
Tool ribbons and their colour systems



3.1.6 5. Working with Files

Creating documents within NVivo
Importing internal documents
Supported file types: Word, PDF, Audio, Video, Images, Survey data



3.1.7 6. Making Descriptions on Pictures

Describing visual data
Linking notes to image regions
Using descriptive metadata for analysis



3.1.8 7. Transcribing Audio and Video Files

Transcribing within NVivo
Working with transcripts only
Working with media only
NVivo Transcription Services (if applicable to current version)



3.1.9 8. Notes: Memos and Annotations

When to use memos
Linked vs.¬†unlinked memos
Annotations: Adding quick comments
Organising your thoughts and reflective writing



3.1.10 9. Coding: The Core of NVivo

Structural coding

Classifications, Cases, Autocoding

Exploratory coding

Manual nodes, in-vivo coding, thematic development

Theoretical coding

Node hierarchies, cataloguing, refining codes, team consistency




3.1.11 10. Queries

Text searches
Word frequency
Coding queries
Matrix coding
Crosstabs
Framework matrices



3.1.12 11. Going Further
This course is designed as a foundation. To continue building your skills with NVivo, consider:

3.1.12.1 Official NVivo Training
QSR International offers both synchronous and asynchronous tutorials, including a student-discounted certification path.
https://www.qsrinternational.com/nvivo-training


3.1.12.2 Books

Qualitative Data Analysis with NVivo by Bazeley & Jackson (Sage)
The Coding Manual for Qualitative Researchers by Johnny Saldana
Handling Qualitative Data by Lyn Richards



3.1.12.3 Video Tutorials

QSR International YouTube Channel
Graham Gibbs‚Äô YouTube



3.1.12.4 CAQDAS Project

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
3.1 About This Version
The version currently used at the University of Sheffield is NVivo 14.
Please make sure you and any collaborators are working on the same version to avoid compatibility issues.

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Projects created in NVivo 14 are not backwards-compatible with earlier versions.
However, older project files (v12 and earlier) can be safely opened in NVivo 14.

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
section: 3.2 Accessing NVivo Through the University of Sheffield
text:
3.2 Accessing NVivo Through the University of Sheffield
To request access to NVivo:

Go to https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/software/
Make sure you‚Äôre signed in to MUSE with your university credentials.
Scroll down to NVivo and click on Request NVivo.




Request NVivo through Software Hub

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
3.3 Email Confirmation
You will receive a confirmation email from IT Services after your request has been processed.



Email confirmation

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
3.4 Installation Instructions
There are two paths depending on the type of machine you are using.

3.4.1 A. University-Managed Devices (e.g.¬†YoYo desktop)
If you are using a University-managed laptop or a desktop on campus:

Open the Software Center on your device.
Search for and select NVivo 14.
Click Install.




Installing from Software Center





3.4.2 B. Personal Laptops
If you are using your own laptop, follow these steps:

Visit https://lumivero.com/customer-login/
Sign in using your credentials (or create an account).
Download the appropriate installer for your system (Windows or Mac).
Use the license key from the university email during activation.

We cannot guarantee the exact install process for personal machines, so please refer to Lumivero‚Äôs help pages if needed.

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
3.5 Activating NVivo
Once NVivo is installed and you open it for the first time, you‚Äôll see a NVivo Setup window.

Fill out the required fields (marked in red)
Paste in the license key from your confirmation email
Click Activate




License activation screen

title: 3¬† Installing NVivo
text:
3.6 Final Setup
Once activation is complete, you will be asked to fill in your personal details. Complete the fields and press OK to finish setup.



Final setup screen



You‚Äôre now ready to start using NVivo üéâ

title: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project
text:
4.1 Opening NVivo
To open NVivo on Windows, go to the Start Menu, navigate to the QSR folder, and select NVivo 14. Upon launch, you‚Äôll be greeted with a welcome screen.
crumbs: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project

title: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project
text:
Note



Some options like ‚ÄúSign In‚Äù and ‚ÄúCollaboration Cloud‚Äù may not apply to institutional users (e.g., University of Sheffield), and will show a message if not configured.



4.1.1 Useful Areas on the Start Screen

Getting Started
This section includes video tutorials and guides on:

Preparing transcripts for import
Formatting survey data for NVivo
Conducting thematic analysis
Writing memos or journals

Help System
NVivo uses a question mark (?) icon instead of the word ‚ÄúHelp‚Äù. Look for this icon throughout the software to access help resources.
Learn and Connect
Includes links to NVivo‚Äôs learning materials and social platforms.
Recent Projects
A quick-access list of projects you‚Äôve recently worked on.
crumbs: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project

title: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project
text:
4.2 Creating a New Project
To start working in NVivo, you‚Äôll need to create a project file. This file will hold all your: - Interview transcripts - Coding - Annotations - Queries - Reports

4.2.1 Steps

Click the New Project button (white button on the left).
A dialog box will appear asking you to:

Name your project
Choose a save location
Optionally, add a description


Once saved, your project will open and you can begin importing data or documents.






Tip



Use clear, concise project names. For example: qualitative_study_2025.nvp
crumbs: 4¬† Opening NVivo and Creating a Project

title: 5¬† The NVivo Interface
text:
5.1 NVivo Environment Overview
Once you create or open a project in NVivo, you‚Äôll see the main workspace ‚Äî a clean layout divided into useful panes, tabs, and ribbons.
To give you a proper tour, it‚Äôs easier to use a sample project so that the screen contains actual data and features to show.

title: 5¬† The NVivo Interface
text:
5.2 The Ribbon
The Ribbon in NVivo is the toolbar that runs along the top. It contains all major tools and is grouped into several tabs:

5.2.1 File (Blue Button)

Opens the Project menu, which allows you to save, close, or copy the project.
Opens a separate screen (not a ribbon).
Used occasionally, mostly for file-level operations.



5.2.2 Home Tab

Central hub for common actions:

Coding
Running queries
Viewing data visualizations




5.2.3 Import Tab

Used to bring external content into NVivo:

Word, PDF, images, video/audio
Survey data (e.g., from Qualtrics)
Bibliographic data (EndNote, Mendeley)




5.2.4 Create Tab

Lets you create content within NVivo:

Documents and memos (basic word processing tools included)
Framework matrices
Nodes (codes)








Tip



You can write directly in NVivo instead of using Word or Google Docs ‚Äî great for journaling or annotations.




5.2.5 Explore Tab

Access searches and exploration tools.
Go beyond coding with:

Word frequency and text search
Cluster analysis
Social network analysis








Note



NVivo‚Äôs search and exploration tools have been core to its power since the early **Nud*IST** days.




5.2.6 Share Tab

Export your work to share with others:

Reports as Word or Excel
Images of visualizations
Codebooks or queries


Note: NVivo doesn‚Äôt support direct posting to social media or emailing content.


5.2.7 Modules Tab

Integrates with extra NVivo modules:

Transcription service (automated, paid)
Collaboration Cloud (not currently supported by all institutions)
Microsoft OneDrive integration








Warning



Always check with your institution about data protection before using cloud-based features like Collaboration Cloud.

title: 5¬† The NVivo Interface
text:
5.3 Contextual Ribbons
Contextual ribbons appear based on what you‚Äôre working on.
For example, if you‚Äôre editing a document, you‚Äôll see the Document ribbon with relevant tools. If you‚Äôre not in a document, it disappears.
This can be confusing ‚Äî just remember: where you click matters.

title: 5¬† The NVivo Interface
text:
5.4 Top-Right Utility Icons
At the top-right of the NVivo window, you‚Äôll see small icons:

Login icon ‚Äì Often non-functional in institutional setups
Save icon ‚Äì Save your current project (like other apps)


This completes the visual and functional tour of NVivo‚Äôs interface.

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.1 About NVivo Projects
In NVivo, everything you work on‚Äîtranscripts, codes, annotations, memos, and queries‚Äîis saved within a single project file. Creating a project is the first step before you can begin importing data or doing any analysis.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.2 Version Compatibility
The University of Sheffield currently uses NVivo 14.

‚ö†Ô∏è Projects created in NVivo 14 are not backwards-compatible with earlier versions.
However, older NVivo projects (v12 and earlier) can be opened in NVivo 14.

Ensure that everyone you collaborate with is using the same version to avoid compatibility issues.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.3 Starting a New Project
To begin, open NVivo and click the New Project button on the welcome screen.
This opens a setup dialog with several fields to complete.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
section: 6.4 Project Title, File Name, and Save Location
text:
6.4 Project Title, File Name, and Save Location
You‚Äôll first be prompted to provide a project title. This name appears in the NVivo interface.
Then, NVivo will auto-generate a file name (e.g., My Project.nvp) and a default save location. You can change these by clicking the Browse button:

Change the directory by navigating to your preferred folder
Change the file name directly in the file name field


üí° Example: Instead of Interviews with Volunteers, you might save your file as volunteers.nvp

Note: Changing the file name does not change the project title‚Äîthese are independent fields.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.5 Description and Language
You can also add a short description of your project. For example:

‚ÄúThese interviews were conducted in 2024 as part of a qualitative study on student volunteering.‚Äù

Then, choose the Text Content Language from the dropdown (e.g., English (UK)).
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.6 Autosave and Recovery Settings
After clicking Next, you‚Äôll see options for how NVivo should handle saving and backups.

Autosave (saves every ~15 minutes automatically)
Prompt to Save at regular intervals (e.g., every 30‚Äì60 minutes)

You can change these later in the settings, so don‚Äôt worry too much about getting it perfect.

üí° Autosave is recommended if you‚Äôre concerned about crashes or data loss.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo
text:
6.7 Finishing Setup
Click Create Project to finish the setup.
NVivo may offer to give you a tour of the software. You can skip it or explore it later.

üìù Tip: To avoid seeing the tour again, tick ‚ÄúDo not show tour again‚Äù at the bottom-left of the window.

You‚Äôre now ready to begin importing your data or creating internal documents in your new NVivo project.
crumbs: 6¬† Creating a Project in NVivo

title: 7¬† Creating Documents in NVivo
text:
7.1 Why Create Documents in NVivo?
In most cases, you‚Äôll import transcripts or notes from external files. But there are a few excellent reasons to create documents directly inside NVivo:
Example log entries:

title: 7¬† Creating Documents in NVivo
text:
Activity Logs: Jot down what you did in each session for future reference or team communication.
Fix Transcripts: Correct transcription errors inside NVivo without re-importing or re-coding.
Appendix Material: Useful for documenting your research process in a structured way.


16 Aug ‚Äì Imported volunteer interviews from Melbourne  
19 Aug ‚Äì First pass of Ken‚Äôs interview: initial themes  
30 Aug ‚Äì Ran search for ‚Äúcareer‚Äù, saved query but not results

title: 7¬† Creating Documents in NVivo
text:
7.2 How to Create a Document
There are two main ways:

7.2.1 Method 1: Use the Create Ribbon

Go to the Create tab in the Ribbon.
Click the Document button (page icon).
The ‚ÄúNew Document‚Äù dialog appears.

###Ô∏è Method 2: Right-Click in List View

Go to Files in the Navigation View.
Right-click in the List View and select:

New File > New Document


This approach is great when the Ribbon isn‚Äôt visible or responsive.

title: 7¬† Creating Documents in NVivo
text:
7.3 The New Document Dialog
You‚Äôll see two fields:

Name ‚Äì like a filename (e.g., Activity Diary)
Description ‚Äì longer text (e.g., ‚ÄúShort notes on tasks carried out in NVivo during data analysis.‚Äù)

There‚Äôs also an Attribute Values tab ‚Äî this is typically not needed for journal-like documents.






Tip



Keep a single document as an internal log to track your project‚Äôs progress over time.

title: 7¬† Creating Documents in NVivo
text:
7.4 Contextual Behavior
Once you create or open a document:

The Ribbon updates with new tabs:

Document tab
Edit tab

If nothing shows in the List View, click Refresh or check the filters.







Warning



Right-click menus and ribbon options depend on where you last clicked. If things disappear, check your focus!

title: 8¬† Importing Interview Transcripts
text:
8.1 Why Import?
Most researchers transcribe interviews using Word or a transcription service. Rather than copy/paste or retype content into NVivo, you can import multiple transcripts at once ‚Äî clean, efficient, and avoids rework.

title: 8¬† Importing Interview Transcripts
text:
8.2 Recommended Workflow
We recommend a 3-step process:

8.2.1 1. Prepare NVivo to Receive Transcripts

8.2.1.1 Create a Subfolder

Go to the Files section under Data in the Navigation View.
Create a new folder (e.g., Transcripts).
Give it a clear name and description.

Example: > Folder: Transcripts
> Description: ‚ÄúInterviews on volunteering experiences‚Äù


8.2.1.2 Set Up File Classifications (Optional)
Useful if you want to attach metadata (e.g., gender, role, location) to each transcript file.




8.2.2 2. Prepare Your Transcripts
This step makes the import more structured and helps with later analysis.

8.2.2.1 Speaker Identifiers
Start each speech turn with a label: - Int: Interviewer - PtA, PtB, etc.: Participants
- Or use first names (with caution re: bias & anonymity)
Int: Can you tell me about your volunteer role?
Anna: I started volunteering in 2021...


8.2.2.2 Use Heading Styles
If your interviews follow a structured protocol, use Word‚Äôs Heading 1 / 2 styles for questions or sections. This enables auto-coding by structure.


8.2.2.3 Add Timestamps (for Audio Link)
If syncing to an audio file, insert timestamps like [00:02:15] at the start of each speaker turn. NVivo can use this to sync transcript and audio.




8.2.3 3. Importing the Documents

Navigate to Files in NVivo.
Click the Import tab in the Ribbon.
Choose Documents and select your transcripts from disk.


NVivo won‚Äôt know your last used folder ‚Äî navigate to the correct directory manually.

Imported documents will appear in your project under the selected folder, ready to code, classify, or query.

title: 8¬† Importing Interview Transcripts
text:
8.3 Wrapping Up
Being intentional about how you import and format your transcripts gives you cleaner data and smoother analysis later on.






Tip



Organize early ‚Äî future-you will thank you!

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
text:
9.1 Why Use Notes in NVivo?
NVivo is more than a place to store interview transcripts and codes‚Äîit‚Äôs also a space to capture your reflections, questions, and insights as you work. Creating notes, memos, and annotations helps you document your thinking and track your analysis process.
Notes in NVivo can take different forms: - Memos: Formal or structured notes about your data, coding, themes, or methodology - Annotations: Quick margin-style notes linked directly to specific text or content
These are essential for qualitative transparency, audit trails, and collaboration.

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
text:
9.2 Creating a Memo
To create a standalone memo in NVivo:

Go to the Create tab on the ribbon.
Click Memo.
A new memo window opens‚Äîadd a title, description, and start typing your content.

You can format text, use headings, or insert links to other items in your project.

Example memo titles: - ‚ÄúInterview Impressions ‚Äì Participant A‚Äù - ‚ÄúTheme: Belonging & Exclusion‚Äù - ‚ÄúCodebook Notes ‚Äì April 2024‚Äù

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
section: 9.3 Linking a Memo to a Source
text:
9.3 Linking a Memo to a Source
You can link a memo to a document or transcript:

Open the source
Use the right-hand panel to select Memo Link
Choose an existing memo or create a new one

This helps you keep reflections close to the data they relate to.

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
text:
9.4 Creating Annotations
Annotations are like digital margin notes‚Äîideal for quick thoughts or questions as you read or code.
To add an annotation:

Highlight the text you want to annotate.
Right-click and choose New Annotation.
Type your comment in the annotation pane.

The annotated text will now show a small highlight and link to your note.

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
text:
9.5 Tips for Using Notes Effectively

Keep a running ‚ÄúAnalysis Diary‚Äù memo to track what you did and why
Use memos to compare cases, codes, or reflect on emerging themes
Don‚Äôt overthink formatting‚Äîmemo writing should be flexible and intuitive
Use annotations to ask yourself critical questions (‚ÄúWhat does this mean?‚Äù, ‚ÄúHow does this relate to my theme X?‚Äù)

title: 9¬† Creating Notes in NVivo
text:
9.6 Summary
Memos and annotations are core qualitative tools that help you reflect, record, and think critically about your data. NVivo makes it easy to keep these notes organised and linked to your analysis‚Äîall in one place.
